text: Patient: Yeah. Well, I noticed it hurt, so I tried to take care of it. Iced it and everything else and then about a week later I noticed my leg was swelling and then it moved down my leg into my ankle. Doctor: And you went to the emergency room? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they found it Patient: They all freaked out. Even the doctors, everybody. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Because it was- it ran from here all the way down to my ankle. Yeah. Doctor: So you know, being on the blood thinner for at least three months is sort of the minimum that we have to do. Patient: Right. Doctor: And we could potentially stop it. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then you know, your body if your leg swells up again, that may tell us that we need to really use it for life.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Can I tell you how much that’s gonna increase the fifty/fifty odds? No. Can I tell you that that’s the most aggressive thing we can do for this cancer right now anywhere in the world? Yes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s what you know basically how I take care, how I try to take care of guys like you who are young and I want to hit the cancer really hard. Patient: Right. Doctor: So your choice basically is radiation with hormones or if you want to try a super sort of therapy, with chemo, super hormones, we can do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may have at the start of this study. Uh, uh, and it can change with therapy. So, you would have to repeat it again. Doctor: Uh, that you actually would stay on the Enzalutamide and if you’re AR-V7 positive, well then we have, uh, some of the new list of new therapies that are being used in other tumor types. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even the PET scan. You know, sensitive but not that sensitive. Patient: Right. Doctor: If it’s just a small amount of cells, but it is enough of a sign for me. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay.

Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation?

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. There is the possibility of – obviously we’ll be monitoring your kidney function, liver function, all of that pretty closely and be monitoring you for any side effects. I mean you tell me more than what anybody knows about this medication sometimes. But uh for the most part it seems to have been okay tolerated in the very, very preliminary, very few patients that have been on it. Patient: What about the diabetes? How does that fit in to this discussion? Doctor: We will have to see if it affects sugars and then accordingly adjust your medications for the diabetes. But right now I don’t know for sure that it does or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be monitoring glucose every time anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be…

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
